sections.title: Human Lan\bua\b\t T\tc\fnolo\by and communicativ\t disabiliti\ts: R\tquir\tm\tnts and possibiliti\ts for t\f\t futur\t Marina B. Ruit\tr
, H\tlm\tr Strik
paragraphs: 2 1 Sint M\b\b\ttens\flinie\f Rese\b\tch, Development & Educ\btion, Nijmegen, Hengstd\bl 3, 6522 JV, Nijmegen, The
Nethe\tl\bnds, 2
R\bdboud Unive\tsity, Dept. of Linguistics, E\t\bsmusplein 1, 6525 HT Nijmegen, The Nethe\tl\bnds,
Nede\tl\bndse T\b\blunie, L\bnge Voo\thout 19, 2501 HN The H\bgue, The Nethe\tl\bnds, 4
Tilbu\tg Unive\tsity, Dept. of
Communic\btion \bnd Info\tm\btion Sciences, P.O. Box 90153, 5000 LE Tilbu\tg, The Nethe\tl\bnds.
E-m\bil: m.\tuite\t@m\b\b\ttens\flinie\f.nl, \b.\tietveld@let.\tu.nl, ccucchi\b\tini@t\b\blunie.o\tg, e.j.\f\t\bhme\t@uvt.nl,

w.st\ti\f@let.\tu.nl Abstract Fo\t some ye\b\ts now, the Nede\tl\bndse T\b\blunie (Dutch L\bngu\bge Union) h\bs been \bctive in p\tomoting the development of hum\bn l\bngu\bge technology (HLT) \bpplic\btions fo\t use\ts of Dutch with communic\btion dis\bbilities. The \te\bson is th\bt HLT p\toducts \bnd se\tvices m\by en\bble these use\ts to imp\tove thei\t ve\tb\bl \butonomy \bnd communic\btion s\fills. We sought to identify \b minimum common set of HLT \tesou\tces th\bt is \tequi\ted to develop tools fo\t \b wide \t\bnge of communic\btion dis\bbilities. In o\tde\t to \te\bch this go\bl, we investig\bted the specific HLT needs of communic\btively dis\bbled people \bnd \tel\bted these needs to the unde\tlying HLT softw\b\te components. By \bn\blysing the \bv\bil\bbility \bnd qu\blity of these essenti\bl HLT \tesou\tces, we we\te \bble to identify which of the c\tuci\bl elements need fu\tthe\t \tese\b\tch \bnd development to become us\bble fo\t developing \bpplic\btions fo\t communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch. The \tesults obt\bined in the cu\t\tent su\tvey c\bn be used to info\tm policy institutions on how they c\bn stimul\bte the development of HLT \tesou\tces fo\t this t\b\tget g\toup. In the cu\t\tent study \tesults we\te obt\bined fo\t Dutch, but \b simil\b\t \bpp\to\bch c\bn \blso be used fo\t othe\t l\bngu\bges.

sections.title: 1. Introduction
paragraphs: Dutch l\bngu\bge use\ts with communic\btion dis\bbilities \b\te h\bmpe\ted in thei\t communic\btive effic\bcy \bnd efficiency. Th\bt is, without othe\t people helping them, they m\by not be \bble to get thei\t mess\bge \bc\toss \bdequ\btely \bnd fluently in Dutch. Simil\b\tly, it m\by be difficult fo\t them to unde\tst\bnd wh\bt othe\t people tell them o\t put in w\titing. HLT m\by help to imp\tove thei\t function\bl communic\btion s\fills, bec\buse HLT m\by \bllow them to \testo\te o\t compens\bte thei\t communic\btion diso\tde\t. An ex\bmple on \bph\bsi\b m\by illust\t\bte this. Aph\bsi\b is \b neu\tologic\bl l\bngu\bge diso\tde\t th\bt c\bn \tesult f\tom \b st\to\fe. The f\tequency of \bph\bsics \bmong st\to\fe p\btients typic\blly \t\bnges f\tom 21 to 38% (e.g., Engelte\t et \bl., 2006). Thus, \bt le\bst 21 out of the 100 pe\tsons suffe\ting \b st\to\fe develop \bph\bsi\b in the sub-\bcute ph\bse. Of these 21 pe\tsons, typic\blly 4 p\bss \bw\by, 4 \tecove\t du\ting the fi\tst months post-onset, \bnd 4 \tem\bin \bph\bsic. The outcome of the \tem\bining 9 pe\tsons c\bnnot be p\tedicted \bccu\t\btely (Niewold, 2006). Aph\bsi\b c\bn m\bnifest itself in \bll l\bngu\bge f\bculties, such \bs spo\fen l\bngu\bge p\toduction. The\te \b\te st\tong indic\btions th\bt intensive t\t\bining c\bn imp\tove \bph\bsics’ function\bl communic\btion s\fills (Bhog\bl, Te\bsell, Foley, & Speechley, 2003). Eme\tging HLT technologies m\by fo\t ex\bmple be used to c\te\bte vi\ttu\bl the\t\bpists th\bt help \bph\bsic spe\b\fe\ts to t\t\bin these s\fills (e.g., Che\tney, H\blpe\t, Holl\bnd, & Cole, 2008). Being f\b\t f\tom exh\bustive, we p\tovide two othe\t ex\bmples th\bt illust\t\bte how HLT en\bbles communic\btively dis\bbled people to imp\tove thei\t communic\btion s\fills. Within the Speech Algo\tithms fo\t Clinic\bl \bnd Educ\btion\bl Applic\btions (SPACE) p\toject, speech \tecognition \bnd synthesis technology we\te used to develop \bn \butom\bted \te\bding tuto\t which \bllows (dyslectic) child\ten to t\t\bin thei\t o\t\bl \te\bding pe\tfo\tm\bnce (e.g., Duch\bte\bu et \bl., 2009). Technology th\bt \bssesses the intelligibility of dys\b\tth\tic speech w\bs c\te\bted \bs well (e.g., V\bn Nuffelen, Midd\bg, De Bodt, & M\b\ttens, 2009).1

sections.title: 1.1. Human Lan\bua\b\t T\tc\fnolo\by and communication disabiliti\ts
paragraphs: The Dutch L\bngu\bge Union is \b Dutch-Flemish inte\tgove\tnment\bl o\tg\bnis\btion th\bt \bims \bt c\te\bting the \tight conditions in which spe\b\fe\ts of Dutch c\bn use this l\bngu\bge in \bs m\bny communic\btive settings \bs possible. The le\bding p\tinciple of the effo\tts of the Dutch L\bngu\bge Union is to \bchieve this fo\t \bll use\ts of Dutch, \blso fo\t those with communic\btion dis\bbilities. Ag\binst this b\bc\fg\tound, the Dutch L\bngu\bge Union h\bs been explo\ting the possibilities offe\ted by HLT p\toducts \bnd se\tvices to imp\tove the ve\tb\bl \butonomy of communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch. A fi\tst initi\btive of the Dutch L\bngu\bge Union to investig\bte the potenti\bl of HLT fo\t people with communic\btion dis\bbilities in the Nethe\tl\bnds \bnd Fl\bnde\ts w\bs the su\tvey c\b\t\tied out by Rietveld \bnd Stolte (2005). The \butho\ts inte\tviewed expe\tts f\tom \b v\b\tiety of disciplines cove\ting the v\b\tious g\toups of people with communic\btion dis\bbilities \bnd expe\tts f\tom the HLT secto\t (e.g., he\blth c\b\te p\tovide\ts \bnd p\tovide\ts of \bugment\btive \bnd \blte\tn\btive communic\btion tools). With thei\t \tesponses, it w\bs dete\tmined: (\b) wh\bt HLT tools \b\te cu\t\tently \bv\bil\bble fo\t people with communic\btion dis\bbilities, (b) wh\bt expe\tiences the use\ts h\bve with these tools (in te\tms of qu\blity \bnd \bpplic\bbility), \bnd (c) whethe\t the HLT m\b\t\fet could help to meet the needs th\bt we\te not yet fulfilled. In 2005, Rietveld \bnd Stolte \l \l \l 1 Fo\t det\biled info\tm\btion, see the SPACE home p\bge: http://www.es\bt.\fuleuven.be/psi/sp\t\b\b\f/p\tojects/SPACE/ .

concluded th\bt \blthough people with communic\btion diso\tde\ts in the Nethe\tl\bnds \bnd Fl\bnde\ts \bppe\b\ted to h\bve u\tgent needs th\bt could be fulfilled by HLT \bpplic\btions, these needs we\te not met \bt th\bt time. Although seve\t\bl HLT \bpplic\btions h\bve been developed ove\t the l\bst five ye\b\ts, \bnno 2010, the HLT needs of communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch \b\te not yet completely fulfilled. At le\bst in p\b\tt, this seems to be due to the dive\tsity of the diso\tde\ts unde\tlying the communic\btion dis\bbilities, which m\b\fes it difficult to develop p\toducts th\bt c\bn be used by \tel\btively l\b\tge numbe\ts of communic\btively dis\bbled people.

sections.title: 1.2. A n\tw initiativ\t to inv\tsti\bat\t r\tquir\tm\tnts and possibiliti\ts for t\f\t futur\t
paragraphs: The p\tesent study fo\tms \b continu\btion of the 2005 study
conducted by Rietveld \bnd Stolte. By investig\bting the
specific needs of communic\btively dis\bbled people \bnd
\tel\bting these needs to the HLT softw\b\te components
unde\tlying the \bpplic\btions c\blled fo\t, we sought to
identify \b minimum common set of HLT \tesou\tces th\bt is
\tequi\ted to develop \bs m\bny tools \bs possible fo\t the wide
\t\bnge of communic\btion dis\bbilities. This \tese\b\tch \bim
c\bn be subdivided into seve\t\bl sub-questions: (\b) Which HLT \bpplic\btions should be developed
fo\t use\ts of Dutch with communic\btion
dis\bbilities in o\tde\t to meet thei\t needs? (b) Which HLT softw\b\te components unde\tlie the
\bpplic\btions th\bt \b\te most needed by use\ts of
Dutch with communic\btion dis\bbilities? (c) A\te the essenti\bl HLT \tesou\tces \bv\bil\bble, \bnd –
if so – does the qu\blity suffice? (d) If the qu\blity of \bn essenti\bl HLT \tesou\tce does
not suffice, wh\bt is the \tese\b\tch effo\tt necess\b\ty
to imp\tove its qu\blity?

sections.title: 2. M\tt\fods
paragraphs: As discussed \bbove, the dive\tsity of the diso\tde\ts unde\tlying the communic\btion dis\bbilities \bnd the v\b\tious HLT needs m\b\fe it difficult to develop p\toducts th\bt c\bn be used by l\b\tge g\toups (Rietveld & Stolte, 2005). In o\tde\t to investig\bte whethe\t these difficulties c\bn be ove\tcome, \bt le\bst fo\t the g\te\bte\t p\b\tt, the p\tesent study followed \bn \bpp\to\bch th\bt w\bs simil\b\t to the one \bdopted in p\tep\b\t\btion of the Dutch-Flemish HLT p\tog\t\bmme STEVIN (\b Dutch \bc\tonym fo\t Essenti\bl Speech \bnd L\bngu\bge Technology Resou\tces). This \tese\b\tch \bnd indust\ty stimul\btion p\tog\t\bmme st\b\tted in 2004 unde\t the \buspices of the Dutch L\bngu\bge Union \bnd is funded by the Dutch \bnd Flemish gove\tnments. An impo\tt\bnt element of the STEVIN p\tog\t\bmme w\bs the definition of the B\bsic L\bngu\bge Resou\tces Kit fo\t Dutch (BLARK; D\belem\bns & St\ti\f, 2002). The BLARK concept (K\t\buwe\t, 1998) w\bs \blso used to specify \b b\bsic l\bngu\bge \tesou\tces \fit fo\t othe\t l\bngu\bges, fo\t ex\bmple A\t\bbic (e.g., M\beg\b\b\td, K\t\buwe\t, & Chou\f\ti, 2009) \bnd Swedish (Elenius, Fo\tsbom, & Megyesi, 2006). In the BLARK, the b\bsic softw\b\te components th\bt \b\te essenti\bl fo\t developing HLT \bpplic\btions we\te specified. By \bn\blysing the \bv\bil\bbility \bnd qu\blity of the v\b\tious components, it could be dete\tmined which essenti\bl elements we\te missing o\t did not meet the \tequi\tements. As \b consequence, it w\bs possible to est\bblish which HLT softw\b\te components h\bve to be developed with p\tio\tity. Relev\bnt fo\t the p\tesent su\tvey is th\bt seve\t\bl m\bt\tices we\te used in defining the BLARK fo\t Dutch: A distinction w\bs m\bde between \bpplic\btions, modules, \bnd d\bt\b. As will be discussed below, \b simil\b\t \bpp\to\bch w\bs used in the p\tesent study.

sections.title: 2.1. Matric\ts
paragraphs: A stepping-stone to the p\tesent su\tvey w\bs \b \tound t\bble confe\tence th\bt w\bs o\tg\bnised by the Dutch L\bngu\bge Union on Septembe\t 28, 2007 (Cucchi\b\tini, 2008). Expe\tts f\tom the HLT secto\t \bnd f\tom the clinic\bl field p\b\tticip\bted. At this confe\tence, \b wo\t\fing g\toup of expe\tts w\bs fo\tmed – the MATRIX wo\t\fing g\toup – who discussed which m\bt\tices could be used in d\t\bwing up the HLT \tesou\tces th\bt \b\te \tequi\ted to develop \bpplic\btions fo\t communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch (Cucchi\b\tini et \bl., 2008; St\ti\f, 2008). Du\ting the su\tvey, the m\bt\tices p\toduced by the MATRIX wo\t\fing g\toup we\te \bd\bpted \bs \b \tesult of feedb\bc\f f\tom the clinic\bl field. The following m\bt\tices we\te used to specify the HLT needs \bs b\tought fo\tw\b\td du\ting the \tound t\bble confe\tence \bnd in the inte\tviews with 20 clinic\bl expe\tts:
• Applicati\b\ts x c\b\tv\frsi\b\ts: Wh\bt conve\tsions between communic\btion mod\blities \b\te needed to develop \bn HLT-b\bsed tool?

• C\b\tv\frsi\b\ts x m\bdul\fs: Wh\bt HLT softw\b\te modules unde\tlie e\bch conve\tsion?  In the BLARK, the types of d\bt\b needed to build, imp\tove, o\t ev\blu\bte HLT softw\b\te modules we\te defined \bs well. In the p\tesent study, howeve\t, we did not specify the d\bt\b, bec\buse \b sep\b\t\bte d\bt\bb\bse will be \tequi\ted fo\t e\bch (sub)g\toup of communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch. This is \tel\bted to the f\bct th\bt the v\b\ti\bbility between these use\ts is conside\t\bble. Even within \b p\b\tticul\b\t subg\toup of communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch (e.g., within the g\toup of dys\b\tth\tic spe\b\fe\ts) speech ch\b\t\bcte\tistics m\by v\b\ty to \b g\te\bt extent.
2.1.1. Applications
On the fi\tst \bxis of the m\bt\tices, we desc\tibed the HLT
\bpplic\btions th\bt use\ts of Dutch with communic\btive
dis\bbilities h\bd indic\bted to be in need of. The following
fou\t dimensions we\te distinguished: • The pu\tpose of the \bpplic\btion: di\bgnosis,
monito\ting, \testo\t\btion o\t compens\btion the\t\bpy,
o\t \bugment\btive \bnd \blte\tn\btive communic\btion
(AAC). • The communic\btion function which h\bs to be
fulfilled: \te\bding, w\titing, listening, o\t spe\b\fing. • The t\b\tget g\toup, \bs defined by the unde\tlying
imp\bi\tment: ment\bl/cognitive (e.g., \bph\bsi\b),
senso\ty (e.g., blind), voice \bnd speech (e.g.,
dys\b\tth\ti\b), \bnd moto\t (e.g., Repetitive St\t\bin Inju\ty).

• Age: child\ten \bnd youngste\ts (up to 18 ye\b\ts), \bdults (18 to 65 ye\b\ts), \bnd elde\tly people (65 ye\b\ts o\t olde\t). HLT dem\bnds m\by diffe\t depending on the \bge of the use\ts. Fo\t inst\bnce, \butom\btic speech \tecognition of child\ten needs specific \bdjustment.
2.1.2. Conv\trsions
In o\tde\t to be \bble to specify fo\t e\bch \bnd eve\ty
\bpplic\btion the unde\tlying HLT softw\b\te components, the
\bpplic\btions we\te conside\ted \bs conve\tsions between the
following five communic\btion mod\blities: 1) Spo\fen l\bngu\bge 2) W\titten l\bngu\bge 3) Non-ve\tb\bl: im\bges, \bnim\btions, symbols,
gestu\tes, o\t \bgents 4) T\bctile: B\t\bille o\t 3D-im\bges (with \telief) 5) Concepts: d\bt\b, pictu\tes, o\t \fey wo\tds, such \bs
stoc\f m\b\t\fet \tepo\tts p\tinted in newsp\bpe\ts.
To m\b\fe cle\b\t wh\bt the \tel\btion is between conve\tsions of
mod\blities \bnd (cl\bsses of) technologies, some ex\bmples
\b\te given below:
1 2: speech \tecognition
2 1: speech synthesis
2 2: text modific\btion, summ\b\tizing, indexing,
etc.
2 3: f\tom text to vi\ttu\bl t\bl\fing he\bds, \bgents,

gestu\tes, etc. 2.1.3. Modul\ts On the thi\td \bxis of the m\bt\tices, we specified the HLT softw\b\te modules unde\tlying the conve\tsions between communic\btion mod\blities th\bt communic\btively dis\bbled people need to use to get thei\t mess\bges \bc\toss \bnd/o\t to de\tive the communic\btive intention of othe\t people. Since not \bll conve\tsions could be \te\blised with the BLARK modules (D\belem\bns & St\ti\f, 2002), the following \bddition\bl modules we\te defined:
• Text-to-gestu\tes
• Recognition of gestu\tes
• Text-to-symbols
• Recognition of symbols
• Gene\t\btion of f\bci\bl exp\tession \bnd \b\tticul\btion
on t\bl\fing he\bds
• Recognition of p\bthologic\bl speech

sections.title: 2.2. Proc\tdur\t
paragraphs: Fo\t e\bch \bnd eve\ty HLT need th\bt w\bs b\tought fo\tw\b\td du\ting the \tound t\bble confe\tence o\t in the inte\tviews with the clinic\bl expe\tts, the unde\tlying conve\tsions we\te est\bblished (\bn ex\bmple is given in T\bble 1). As T\bble 1 illust\t\btes, seve\t\bl conve\tsions m\by be needed to develop \b p\b\tticul\b\t HLT \bpplic\btion. In tot\bl, 97 conve\tsions \b\te needed to develop the 65 HLT \bpplic\btions th\bt use\ts of Dutch with communic\btion dis\bbilities seem to \tequi\te.  Requested HLT \bpplic\btion: Writi\tg Aid Desc\tiption: People with mild \bph\bsi\b o\t dyso\ttho-g\t\bphi\b could benefit f\tom \bn \bpplic\btion th\bt they c\bn use when w\titing \b lette\t, p\bpe\t, o\t e-m\bil. It should p\tovide: wo\td p\tediction, sentence p\tediction, spell \bnd g\t\bmm\b\t chec\fe\t tools, \bnd \bdvice on which \tegiste\t to use (e.g., fo\tm\bl o\t info\tm\bl). It should \blso include speech synthesis, bec\buse it \bllows use\ts to monito\t \bnd co\t\tect thei\t own w\titing. L\bstly, use\ts should be \bble to p\toduce \b g\t\bmm\btic\blly well-fo\tmed w\titten sentence by putting symbols into \b sequence. (1) Applic\btion
- - -  - Pu\tpose: AAC Communic\btion function: w\titing T\b\tget g\toup: ment\bl/ cognitive (\bph\bsi\b, dyso\tthog\t\bphi\b) Age: \bll
(2) Conve\tsions  - - - 2 2 2 1 3 2
T\bble 1: Ex\bmple of \b \tequested HLT \bpplic\btion (fo\t

expl\bn\btion see text). 2.2.1. Quantitativ\t analysis of conv\trsions The qu\bntit\btive \bn\blysis of the 97 conve\tsions de\tived with the p\tocedu\te desc\tibed \bbove, yielded \b hie\t\b\tchy of conve\tsions \b\t\t\bnged by descending o\tde\t of occu\t\tence. In the cu\t\tent study, only the five most f\tequently occu\t\ting conve\tsions we\te used fo\t fu\tthe\t \bn\blysis (cf., T\bble 2). T\bble 2 fo\t ex\bmple shows th\bt 32% of the 97 conve\tsions consisted of speech synthesis. One could \b\tgue th\bt the conve\tsions sp\f\fch sy\tth\fsis \bnd sp\f\fch r\fc\bg\titi\b\t do not need to be developed fo\t communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts specific\blly \bs these conve\tsions \b\te \bl\te\bdy (\bt le\bst p\b\tti\blly) \bv\bil\bble fo\t he\blthy use\ts of Dutch. In \b\tguing \bg\binst this st\btement, it is impo\tt\bnt to emph\bsize th\bt these conve\tsions need specific \bdjustments in o\tde\t to be employed in \bpplic\btions fo\t communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts. Fo\t ex\bmple, due to the e\t\to\t-p\tone ch\b\t\bcte\t of \bph\bsic speech (e.g., substitutions of wo\tds, sounds, \bnd ung\t\bmm\btic\bl utte\t\bnces), the \bl\te\bdy \bv\bil\bble speech \tecognition \tesou\tces do not suffice to \tecognise the speech of \bph\bsic spe\b\fe\ts.  Conve\tsion F\tequency (in %)
2 1 Speech synthesis 32
1 2 Speech \tecognition 26
2 2 Text modific\btion 12
3 1 Non-ve\tb\bl to speech 8
2 3 Text to non-ve\tb\bl 7
T\bble 2: Hie\t\b\tchy of the five most f\tequently occu\t\ting
conve\tsions (N = 97).

2.2.2. Ac\fi\tvin\b cons\tnsus The MATRIX wo\t\fing g\toup \bchieved consensus on the softw\b\te modules needed to \te\blise the essenti\bl conve\tsions. Secondly, the MATRIX wo\t\fing g\toup \bg\teed on the \bv\bil\bbility \bnd qu\blity of the softw\b\te modules unde\tlying the five most f\tequently occu\t\ting conve\tsions. An HLT \tesou\tce w\bs conside\ted \bv\bil\bble when it w\bs eithe\t c\bmm\frcially o\t \fxp\frim\f\ttally \bccessible (indic\bted with C \bnd E \tespectively in T\bble 3). Qu\blity w\bs \t\bted \bt \b 4-point \t\bting sc\ble: g\b\bd (G), suffici\f\tt (S), i\tsuffici\f\tt (I), o\t p\b\br (P). In the p\tesent study, only the HLT softw\b\te \tesou\tces \t\bted \bs sufficient o\t good we\te conside\ted to be of \bdequ\bte qu\blity in o\tde\t to be benefici\bl to communic\btively dis\bbled people. L\bstly, the MATRIX wo\t\fing g\toup m\bde \bn estim\btion of the \tese\b\tch effo\tt needed to develop o\t imp\tove HLT softw\b\te modules whose qu\blity \bppe\b\ted not to be up to the st\bnd\b\tds \tequi\ted. Only if \b \tel\btively sm\bll \tese\b\tch effo\tt w\bs expected to be needed in o\tde\t to imp\tove qu\blity o\t to m\b\fe it mo\te suit\bble fo\t \b specific \bpplic\btion, w\bs the complexity of \b specific module \t\bted \bs l\bw (L). Conve\tsely, wheneve\t subst\bnti\bl \tese\b\tch effo\tt w\bs \bnticip\bted to imp\tove qu\blity, the complexity w\bs \t\bted \bs high (H). The l\bbel av\frag\f (A) w\bs given if \bn \bve\t\bge \tese\b\tch effo\tt w\bs \bnticip\bted.

sections.title: 3. R\tsults
paragraphs: In this section, we p\tesent the m\bin \tesults \tel\bting to the sub-questions fo\tmul\bted in the Int\toduction.

sections.title: 3.1. HLT applications r\tquir\td
paragraphs: Although invento\tying the needs of people with communic\btive dis\bbilities constituted the immedi\bte go\bl of the p\tesent su\tvey, it w\bs not its ultim\bte go\bl. The ultim\bte go\bl of the cu\t\tent su\tvey w\bs to define the \bv\bil\bbility \bnd qu\blity of \b minimum set of HLT \tesou\tces th\bt is \tequi\ted to develop \bs m\bny tools \bs possible fo\t the wide \t\bnge of communic\btion dis\bbilities. Fo\t this \te\bson, we do not p\tovide \b complete ove\tview of the HLT \bpplic\btions \tequi\ted (N = 65), but limit ou\tselves to p\toviding some ex\bmples of useful \bpplic\btions in Section 4.2

sections.title: 3.2. Und\trlyin\b HLT softwar\t compon\tnts
paragraphs: T\bble 3 p\tesents the essenti\bl (indic\bted with X) \bnd option\bl (indic\bted with p\b\tenthesis) modules unde\tlying the five most f\tequently occu\t\ting conve\tsions. Fo\t ex\bmple, fo\t the conve\tsion sp\f\fch sy\tth\fsis, the following modules \b\te essenti\bl: graph\fm\f-t\b- ph\b\t\fm\f c\b\tv\frsi\b\t, t\fxt pr\f-pr\bc\fssi\tg, l\fmmatisi\tg & m\brph\bl\bgical a\talysis, m\brph\bsy\ttactic disambiguati\b\t, sy\ttactic a\talysis, pr\bs\bdy g\f\t\frati\b\t, \bnd c\bmpl\ft\f sp\f\fch sy\tth\fsis. The module s\fma\ttic & pragmatic a\talysis is option\bl. \l \l \l 2 Re\bde\ts wishing to obt\bin the enti\te d\bt\b set should cont\bct the fi\tst \butho\t.

sections.title: 3.3. Availability and quality of t\f\t modul\ts
paragraphs: As T\bble 3 illust\t\btes, the \bv\bil\bbility \bnd qu\blity of the essenti\bl modules v\b\ties conside\t\bbly. Some modules \b\te both \bv\bil\bble \bnd of sufficient qu\blity. This holds fo\t ex\bmple fo\t the HLT module l\fmmatisi\tg & m\brph\bl\bgical a\talysis. Howeve\t, not \bll minim\blly \tequi\ted modules \b\te \bv\bil\bble \bnd good enough to be employed fo\t developing \bpplic\btions fo\t communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch. The module t\fxt g\f\t\frati\b\t is neithe\t comme\tci\blly no\t expe\timent\blly \bv\bil\bble. Consequently, its qu\blity is \t\bted \bs poo\t. It seems p\b\t\bdoxic\bl th\bt, \blthough la\tguag\f & dial\fct id\f\ttificati\b\t is not \bv\bil\bble, its qu\blity is \t\bted \bs sufficient. This is due to the f\bct th\bt p\tomising \tesults h\bve been obt\bined in scientific \tese\b\tch; howeve\t, \bn expe\timent\bl ve\tsion of this module is not \bv\bil\bble yet.

sections.title: 3.4. R\ts\tarc\f \tffort n\t\td\td to improv\t quality
paragraphs: Fo\t the HLT \tesou\tces l\bc\fing sufficient qu\blity, the \bnticip\bted \tese\b\tch effo\tt is given in T\bble 3. Fo\t ex\bmple, in o\tde\t to imp\tove the qu\blity of the module r\fc\bg\titi\b\t path\bl\bgical sp\f\fch \b subst\bnti\bl \tese\b\tch effo\tt is needed. This is due to the conside\t\bble v\b\ti\bbility in speech p\toduction between \bnd within communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch.

sections.title: 4. Conclusions
paragraphs: The most impo\tt\bnt question of the cu\t\tent su\tvey is which HLT \tesou\tces need to be developed o\t imp\toved fi\tst in o\tde\t to fulfil the needs of communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch best. As discussed in the Int\toduction, the c\tite\tion of multipl\f-usability w\bs used in the p\tesent su\tvey. Put diffe\tently, we sought to identify \b minimum set of HLT \tesou\tces th\bt is \tequi\ted to develop \bs m\bny tools \bs possible fo\t the wide \t\bnge of communic\btion dis\bbilities. It is howeve\t impo\tt\bnt to emph\bsize th\bt othe\t c\tite\ti\b c\bn be used to \bnswe\t the question p\tesented \bbove, such \bs pr\fval\f\tc\f \bnd s\fv\frity \bf th\f c\bmmu\ticati\b\t dis\brd\fr. In \bddition, f\fasibility c\bn be used \bs \b c\tite\tion, \bs is illust\t\bted by the su\tvey of the Flemish Gove\tnment dep\b\ttment EWI (Dutch \bc\tonym fo\t Economics, Science, \bnd Innov\btion; Kenis, 2009). In the p\tesent su\tvey, howeve\t, we did not use fe\bsibility \bs \b c\tite\tion bec\buse the development \bnd imp\tovement of HLT \tesou\tces is di\tectly \tel\bted to the \bmount of \tese\b\tch budget \bv\bil\bble. Fo\t th\bt \te\bson, we will \test\tict ou\tselves to summ\b\tising the \bv\bil\bbility \bnd qu\blity of the essenti\bl HLT \tesou\tces unde\tlying the five most f\tequently occu\t\ting conve\tsions.3

In the following sections, we will summ\b\tise the \tese\b\tch effo\tt \bnticip\bted to imp\tove the qu\blity of the HLT \tesou\tces \bs well.  \l \l \l 3 Fo\t cl\b\tity’s s\b\fe, the \bv\bil\bbility \bnd qu\blity of the option\bl modules is not discussed in this section (fo\t info\tm\btion \bbout these modules, see T\bble 3).
T\bble 3: Essenti\bl (X) \bnd option\bl ( ) HLT \tesou\tces unde\tlying the five most f\tequently occu\t\ting conve\tsions,
including availability of e\bch softw\b\te module (C = comme\tci\blly, E = expe\timent\blly \bccessible), its quality (G = good,
S = sufficient, I = insufficient, o\t P = poo\t), \bs well \bs its c\bmpl\fxity (i.e., the \tese\b\tch effo\tt \bnticip\bted to develop o\t
imp\tove the HLT softw\b\te module: L = low, A = \bve\t\bge, o\t H = high).
\b,b P\tosody gene\t\btion \bnd complete speech synthesis \b\te necess\b\ty fo\t conve\tting text to NmG o\t SMOG (Dutch
\bc\tonyms fo\t spo\fen l\bngu\bge suppo\tted by gestu\tes).

4.1. Concludin\b r\tmarks on sp\t\tc\f synt\f\tsis Speech synthesis is the most f\tequently occu\t\ting conve\tsion unde\tlying the tools needed by communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch. All seven essenti\bl modules \b\te \bv\bil\bble \bnd - except fo\t t\fxt pr\f-pr\bc\fssi\tg - h\bve sufficient o\t good qu\blity (cf., T\bble 3). A \tel\btively sm\bll \tese\b\tch effo\tt is \bnticip\bted to imp\tove the qu\blity of the l\btte\t module. Thus, by imp\toving the qu\blity of only one module, \bpplic\btions b\bsed on speech synthesis c\bn be developed. T\bble 4 gives \bn ex\bmple of \b speech synthesis-b\bsed \bpplic\btion th\bt communic\btively dis\bbled \bppe\b\t to find useful. Hie\t\b\tchy 5 most f\tequently occu\t\ting conve\tsions 1 (32%) 1 (26%) 3 (12%) 4 (8%) 5 (7%)  Speech synthesis Speech \tecognition Text modifi-c\btion Nonve\tb\bl to speech Text to nonve\tb\bl Av\bil\bbility HLT softw\b\te modules 2 1 1 2 2 2 3 1 2 3 C E Qu\blity Complexity G\t\bpheme-to-phoneme conve\tsion X X X y y G n/\b Text p\te-p\tocessing X X X y y I L Lemm\btising & mo\tphologic\bl \bn\blysis X X X y y G n/\b Mo\tphosynt\bctic dis\bmbigu\btion X X X y y G n/\b Synt\bctic \bn\blysis X X X X y y S n/\b Sem\bntic & p\t\bgm\btic \bn\blysis ( ) X X X n n P H Text gene\t\btion X X n n P A BL A RK  f o \t  l \b n g u \b g e  t e c h n o l o g y  L\bngu\bge-p\bi\t dependent t\t\bnsl\btion modules ( ) y y I H P\tosody \tecognition ( ) n n P A P\tosody gene\t\btion X X X \b
y y S n/\b Complete speech synthesis X X X b

y y G n/\b Complete speech \tecognition X y y I A Phone st\ting comput\btion ( ) y y G n/\b Robust speech \tecognition X y y P H Spe\b\fe\t identific\btion ( ) y y S n/\b L\bngu\bge & di\blect identific\btion ( ) n n S

n/\b Ad\bpt\btion X y n S n/\b BL A RK  f o \t  S p e e c h  t e c h n o l o g y  Confidence me\bsu\tes & utte\t\bnce ve\tific\btion X y y I A Text-to-gestu\tes X n y I A Recognition of gestu\tes X n y I H Text-to- symbols X y n I A Recognition of symbols X n n P L Gene\t\btion of f\bci\bl exp\tession & \b\tticul\btion on t\bl\fing he\bds X n y I L A d d i t i o n \b l  m o d u l e s  Recognition p\bthologic\bl speech X n n P H

Requested HLT \bpplic\btion: Sp\f\fch c\b\tv\frsi\b\t Desc\tiption: pe\tson\blized synthetic speech is c\te\bted on spe\b\fe\t’s own voice \teco\tdings \bt \bn e\b\tly st\bge of thei\t dise\bse. (1) Applic\btion

- -  -    - Pu\tpose: AAC Communic\btion function: spe\b\fing T\b\tget g\toup: voice & speech (e.g., p\tog\tessive dise\bses such \bs Amyot\tophic L\bte\t\bl Scle\tosis o\t l\b\tynx exti\tp\btion) Age: \bdults \bnd elde\tly
(2) Conve\tsion - 1 1
T\bble 4: Ex\bmple of \b \tequested HLT \bpplic\btion b\bsed

on speech synthesis 4.2. Concludin\b r\tmarks on sp\t\tc\f r\tco\bnition Speech \tecognition is the second most f\tequently occu\t\ting conve\tsion unde\tlying the tools needed by communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch. As T\bble 3 illust\t\btes, m\bny HLT \tesou\tces need to be developed o\t imp\toved in o\tde\t to en\bble communic\btively dis\bbles use\ts of Dutch to benefit f\tom speech \tecognition. Fou\t out of the five essenti\bl HLT modules \b\te \bv\bil\bble. Howeve\t, only one (i.e., adaptati\b\t) is of sufficient qu\blity. The \tese\b\tch effo\tt needed to imp\tove the qu\blity of the \tem\bining fou\t modules \t\bnges f\tom \bve\t\bge (c\bmpl\ft\f sp\f\fch r\fc\bg\titi\b\t \bnd c\b\tfid\f\tc\f m\fasur\fs & utt\fra\tc\f v\frificati\b\t) to high (r\bbust sp\f\fch r\fc\bg\titi\b\t \bnd r\fc\bg\titi\b\t path\bl\bgical sp\f\fch). As indic\bted befo\te, \b subst\bnti\bl \tese\b\tch effo\tt is needed in o\tde\t to develop the module r\fc\bg\titi\b\t path\bl\bgical sp\f\fch. This is due to the conside\t\bble between \bnd within-subject v\b\ti\bbility in p\bthologic\bl speech p\toduction. An ex\bmple of \bn HLT th\bt is b\bsed on speech \tecognition is given in T\bble 5.  Requested HLT \bpplic\btion: C\b\tv\frsati\b\t a\talysis Desc\tiption: the conve\ts\btion between communic\btively dis\bbled spe\b\fe\t \bnd thei\t conve\ts\btion p\b\ttne\ts should be t\t\bnsc\tibed \butom\btic\blly. It should be possible to \bn\blyse the l\bngu\bge (e.g., synt\bx, p\t\bgm\btics) o\t speech ch\b\t\bcte\tistics (e.g., inton\btion, speech \t\bte) of the speech s\bmple \bs well. (1) Applic\btion

- - -    - Pu\tpose: di\bgnosis, the\t\bpy Commun. function: spe\b\fing T\b\tget g\toup: ment\bl/cognition (e.g., \bph\bsi\b), voice \bnd speech (e.g., stutte\ting), moto\t (e.g., ve\tb\bl \bp\t\bxi\b) Age: \bll
(2) Conve\tsion - 1 2
T\bble 5: Ex\bmple of \b \tequested HLT \bpplic\btion b\bsed

on speech \tecognition 4.3. Concludin\b r\tmarks on t\txt modification Fou\t out of the six HLT modules necess\b\ty to execute text modific\btion \b\te \bv\bil\bble. Except fo\t t\fxt pr\f-pr\bc\fssi\tg, \bll \bv\bil\bble modules \b\te of sufficient o\t good qu\blity. As indic\bted in P\b\t\bg\t\bph 4.1., \b sm\bll \tese\b\tch effo\tt is needed to imp\tove t\fxt pr\f-pr\bc\fssi\tg. The modules s\fma\ttic & pragmatic a\talysis \bnd t\fxt g\f\t\frati\b\t \b\te \blso essenti\bl fo\t text modific\btion; howeve\t, none of these two modules is \bv\bil\bble yet. The complexity of these modules is high \bnd \bve\t\bge \tespectively. An illust\t\btion of \bn \bpplic\btion th\bt – in p\b\tt - is b\bsed on text modific\btion is given in T\bble 6.  Requested HLT \bpplic\btion: Summarisi\tg Desc\tiption: the \bpplic\btion should \butom\btic\blly summ\b\tise texts in spo\fen o\t w\titten fo\tm. (1) Applic\btion
- - -   - Pu\tpose: AAC Communic\btion function: \te\bding T\b\tget g\toup: ment\bl/cognition (e.g., dyslexi\b, \bph\bsi\b, \bnd ment\bl \tet\b\td\btion). Age: \bll
(2) Conve\tsions - - 2 2 1 2
T\bble 6: Ex\bmple of \b \tequested HLT \bpplic\btion b\bsed

on text modific\btion 4.4. Concludin\b r\tmarks on non-v\trbal to sp\t\tc\f Five out of the eight HLT modules essenti\bl to conve\tt im\bges, \bnim\btions, symbols, gestu\tes, o\t \bgents (i.e., non-ve\tb\bl) into speech \b\te \bv\bil\bble. Except fo\t r\fc\bg\titi\b\t \bf g\fstur\fs, \bll \bv\bil\bble modules \b\te of sufficient o\t good qu\blity. A l\b\tge \tese\b\tch effo\tt is needed to imp\tove r\fc\bg\titi\b\t \bf g\fstur\fs. S\fma\ttic & pragmatic a\talysis, t\fxt g\f\t\frati\b\t, \bnd symb\bl r\fc\bg\titi\b\t \b\te essenti\bl \bs well in this conve\tsion; howeve\t, not \bccessible yet. The \tese\b\tch effo\tts needed to imp\tove these modules v\b\ties f\tom low (symb\bl r\fc\bg\titi\b\t), \bve\t\bge (t\fxt g\f\t\frati\b\t), to high (s\fma\ttic & pragmatic a\talysis). T\bble 7 illust\t\btes \bn HLT \bpplic\btion th\bt is b\bsed on non-ve\tb\bl to speech.  Requested HLT \bpplic\btion: Pict\bgram writi\tg aid Desc\tiption: the \bpplic\btion should \butom\btic\blly gene\t\bte \b g\t\bmm\btic\blly well-fo\tmed sentence b\bsed on the pictog\t\bms selected \bnd sequenced. (1) Applic\btion
- - -   - Pu\tpose: AAC Communic\btion function: w\titing T\b\tget g\toup: ment\bl/cognition (e.g., dyso\tthog\t\bphi\b, \bph\bsi\b, \bnd ment\bl \tet\b\td\btion). Age: \bll
(2) Conve\tsion - 3 2
T\bble 7: Ex\bmple of \b \tequested HLT \bpplic\btion b\bsed
on non-ve\tb\bl to speech

4.5. Concludin\b r\tmarks on t\txt to non-v\trbal Ten out of the eleven HLT modules th\bt \b\te necess\b\ty to conve\tt text into im\bges, \bnim\btions, symbols, gestu\tes, o\t \bgents (i.e., non-ve\tb\bl) \b\te \bv\bil\bble. Howeve\t, only six out of these 10 modules \b\te of sufficient qu\blity. The \tese\b\tch effo\tts needed to imp\tove the qu\blity of the modules th\bt do not meet the \tequi\tements yet \t\bnges f\tom low (t\fxt pr\f-pr\bc\fssi\tg \bnd g\f\t\frati\b\t \bf facial \fxpr\fssi\b\t & articulati\b\t \b\t talki\tg h\fads), \bve\t\bge (t\fxt-t\b-g\fstur\fs \bnd t\fxt-t\b-symb\bls), to high (s\fma\ttic & pragmatic a\talysis) T\bble 8 illust\t\btes \bn HLT \bpplic\btion th\bt – in p\b\tt – is b\bsed on non-ve\tb\bl to speech.  Requested HLT \bpplic\btion: Sig\t la\tguag\f tra\tslat\br Desc\tiption: De\bf \bnd h\b\td of he\b\ting people do not \blw\bys comp\tehend w\titten l\bngu\bge well enough to unde\tst\bnd wh\bt othe\ts put in w\titing o\t tell them. Fo\t this \te\bson, the \bpplic\btion should \butom\btic\blly conve\tt spo\fen o\t w\titten l\bngu\bge into sign l\bngu\bge. (1) Applic\btion
- -  -  - Pu\tpose: the\t\bpy, AAC Communic\btion function: \te\bding \bnd listening T\b\tget g\toup: senso\ty (e.g., de\bf \bnd h\b\td of he\b\ting). Age: \bll
(2) Conve\tsions - - 1 3 2 3
T\bble 8: Ex\bmple of \b \tequested HLT \bpplic\btion b\bsed

on text to non-ve\tb\bl 4.6. Final r\tmarks Afte\t d\t\bwing the conclusions p\tesented in the p\teceding sections, we would li\fe to m\b\fe \b fin\bl comment. The question which HLT \tesou\tces need to be developed o\t imp\toved fi\tst in o\tde\t to fulfil the needs of communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts of Dutch best, is \bn impo\tt\bnt one. Howeve\t, we \b\te well \bw\b\te th\bt the \bnswe\t is mo\te difficult th\bn the question itself. In p\b\tt this is due to the f\bct th\bt seve\t\bl c\tite\ti\b c\bn be used in p\toviding \bn \bnswe\t. Although multipl\f-usability w\bs used \bs \b c\tite\tion in this study, we sought to p\tesent the \tesults in such \b w\by th\bt othe\t c\tite\ti\b could \blso be used in \bn\blysing the \tesults obt\bined. Acco\tdingly, these \tesults c\bn be used to info\tm policy institutions on how they c\bn stimul\bte the development of HLT \tesou\tces fo\t the g\toup of communic\btively dis\bbled use\ts. In the cu\t\tent study \tesults we\te obt\bined fo\t Dutch, but \b simil\b\t \bpp\to\bch c\bn \blso be used fo\t othe\t l\bngu\bges.

sections.title: 5. Acknowl\td\b\tm\tnts
paragraphs: We \b\te indebted to the (othe\t) membe\ts of the MATRIX wo\t\fing g\toup (Di\t\f Lemb\techts, Hugo V\bn h\bmme, Lili\bn Beije\t, \bnd Vincent de Jong), \bll inte\tviewees \bnd p\b\tticip\bnts of the \tound t\bble confe\tence of Septembe\t 28, 2007 (too m\bny to n\bme in pe\tson) \bs well \bs Ant\bl v\bn den Bosch, Onno C\t\bsbo\tn, Inge de Mönnin\f, B\b\tt Noë, A\tthu\t Di\t\fsen, Michel Boe\festein, Remco v\bn Veenend\b\bl, Loes Theunissen, \bnd M\b\tie P\tuyn fo\t thei\t v\blu\bble cont\tibution to the wo\t\f p\tesented in this p\bpe\t.

Duch\bte\bu, J., Kong, Y.O., Cleu\ten, L., L\bt\bcz, L., Roelens, J., S\bmi\t, A., Demuync\f,, K. Ghesquiè\te, P. Ve\thelst W., V\bn h\bmme, H. (2009). Developing \b \te\bding tuto\t: Design \bnd ev\blu\btion of dedic\bted speech \tecognition \bnd synthesis modules. Sp\f\fch C\bmmu\ticati\b\t, 51, 985-994.
Elenius, K., Fo\tsbom, E., & Megyesi, B. (2006). L\bngu\bge Resou\tces \bnd Tools fo\t Swedish: A Su\tvey. Pr\bc\f\fdi\tgs LREC.

Engelte\t, S.T., Gostyns\fi, M., P\bp\b, S., F\tei, M., Bo\tn, C., Ajd\bcic-G\toss, et \bl. (2006). Epidemiology of Aph\bsi\b Att\tibut\bble to Fi\tst Ischemic St\to\fe. Incidence, Seve\tity, Fluency, Etiology, \bnd Th\tombolysis. Str\bk\f, 37, 1379-1384.
